newsitem.title: MEXICO: Chile sees Clinton re-election boosting Nafta hopes.
newsitem.headline: Chile sees Clinton re-election boosting Nafta hopes.

text.p: Chile's Finance Minister on Wednesday said U.S. President Bill Clinton's re-election may bolster chances of achieving "fast-track" status to join the North American Free Trade Agreement.

"The United States is a question mark...I hope that at some point, sooner rather than later, President Clinton will put his own weight behind a global fast-track project. Now he's re-elected he's more popular," Finance Minister Eduardo Aninat told reporters.
Aninat, attending a Latin American investment conference in this Caribbean resort, said Chile was not staking everything on NAFTA membership.

Chile, Latin America's strongest economy, was supposed to become a full member of the treaty with United States, Mexico and Canada in mid-1996, but was frustrated in its bid chiefly because the U.S. Congress resisted granting "fast-track" authority which speeds the approval process.
"I hope (fast-track) happens," Aninat said. "If it does Chile will negotiate firmly, well, as it should, and if it doesn't occur we will continue advancing with other treaties."
President Eduardo Frei was due to visit the White House next month and he evidently will press Clinton to throw his personal backing behind fast-track.
"What we still don't see is a fast-track project from the White House, that's the weight that's missing, the rest is very positive good intentions," Aninat said.

Chile signed a NAFTA-style agreement with Canada last year and also has a free trade agreement with Mexico. Seperately, last year it signed a trade treaty with the trading bloc that includes Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay.
